abstract.p: Court in Paris rejects request to reduce voting rights of Taittinger family, which controls 55 percent of shareholder votes in Societe du Louvre, dealing blow to efforts by American takeover specialist, Asher B Edelman, to wrest control of Societe du Louvre of France from Taittinger family; court orders Edelman to pay $33,250 in damages to 23 shareholders, including 20 members of Taittinger family; photo (S)

block.p: Dealing a blow to efforts by the American takeover specialist, Asher B. Edelman, to wrest control of Societe du Louvre of France from the Taittinger family, a court in Paris rejected a request to reduce the voting rights of the Taittingers, who control 55 percent of the shareholder votes in Societe du Louvre. Mr. Edelman and other American investors have been seeking control of Societe du Louvre; its assets include the elegant Hotel de Crillon in Paris and the Baccarat crystal works. The court ordered Mr. Edelman to pay $33,250 in damages to 23 shareholders of Societe du Louvre, including 20 members of the Taittinger family. The Taittinger family also owns Taittinger Champagne. A lawyer for Mr. Edelman said he would appeal the decision.
